Deprecation of AS_SET and AS_CONFED_SET in BGP Deprecation of AS_SET in BGP
draft-ietf-idr-deprecate-as-set-confed-set-08 draft-ietf-idr-deprecate-as-set-confed-set-09
Abstract Abstract
BCP 172 (i.e., RFC 6472) recommends not using AS_SET and BCP 172 (i.e., RFC 6472) recommends not using AS_SET in the Border
AS_CONFED_SET in the Border Gateway Protocol. This document advances Gateway Protocol. This document advances this recommendation to a
this recommendation to a standards requirement in BGP; it proscribes standards requirement in BGP; it proscribes the use of the AS_SET
the use of the AS_SET and AS_CONFED_SET types of path segments in the type of path segments in the AS_PATH. This is done to simplify the
AS_PATH. This is done to simplify the design and implementation of design and implementation of BGP and to make the semantics of the
BGP and to make the semantics of the originator of a route clearer. originator of a route clearer. This will also simplify the design,
This will also simplify the design, implementation, and deployment of implementation, and deployment of various BGP security mechanisms.
various BGP security mechanisms. This document (if approved) updates This document (if approved) updates RFC 4271 and RFC 5065, and
RFC 4271 and RFC 5065 by eliminating AS_SET and AS_CONFED_SET types, obsoletes RFC 6472.
and obsoletes RFC 6472.

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
BCP 172 [RFC6472] makes a recommendation for not using AS_SET (see BCP 172 [RFC6472] makes a recommendation for not using AS_SET (see
[RFC4271]) and AS_CONFED_SET (see [RFC5065]) in the Border Gateway [RFC4271]) and AS_CONFED_SET (see [RFC5065]) in the Border Gateway
Protocol (BGP). This document advances the BCP recommendation to a Protocol (BGP). This document advances the BCP recommendation to a
standards requirement in BGP; it proscribes the use of the AS_SET and standards requirement in BGP; it proscribes the use of the AS_SET
AS_CONFED_SET types of path segments in the AS_PATH. typeS of path segments in the AS_PATH.
The AS_SET path segment in the AS_PATH attribute (Sections 4.3 and The AS_SET path segment in the AS_PATH attribute (Sections 4.3 and
5.1.2 of [RFC4271]) is created by a router that is performing route 5.1.2 of [RFC4271]) is created by a router that is performing route
aggregation and contains an unordered set of Autonomous Systems aggregation and contains an unordered set of Autonomous Systems
(ASes) that contributing prefixes in the aggregate have traversed. (ASes) that contributing prefixes in the aggregate have traversed.
The AS_CONFED_SET path segment (see [RFC5065]) in the AS_PATH
attribute is created by a router that is performing route aggregation
and contains an unordered set of Member AS Numbers in the local
confederation that contributing prefixes in the aggregate have
traversed. It is very similar to an AS_SET but is used within a
confederation.
By performing aggregation, a router is combining multiple existing By performing aggregation, a router is combining multiple BGP routes
routes into a single new route. The aggregation together with the for more specific destinations into a new route for a less specific
use of AS_SET blurs the semantics of origin AS for the prefix being destination. ([RFC4271], Section 9.1.2.2.) Aggregation may blur the
announced. Therefore, the aggregation with AS_SET (or AS_CONFED_SET) semantics of the origin AS for the prefix being announced by
can cause operational issues, such as not being able to authenticate producing an AS_SET. AS_SETs can cause operational issues, such as
a route origin for the aggregate prefix in new BGP security not being able to authenticate a route origin for the aggregate
technologies such as those that take advantage of X.509 extensions prefix in new BGP security technologies such as those that take
for IP addresses and AS identifiers [RFC3779] [RFC6480] [RFC6811] advantage of X.509 extensions for IP addresses and AS identifiers
[RFC8205]. This in turn could result in reachability problems for ([RFC3779], [RFC6480], [RFC6811],[RFC6907], [RFC8205]). This in turn
the aggregated prefix and its components (i.e., more specific could result in reachability problems for the aggregated prefix and
prefixes). its components; i.e., more specific prefixes.
From analysis of past Internet routing data, it is apparent that From analysis of historical Internet routing data, it is apparent
aggregation that involves AS_SETs is very seldom used in practice on that aggregation that involves AS_SETs is very seldom used in
the public Internet [Analysis] and when it is used, it is often used practice on the public Internet [Analysis]. When it is used, it is
incorrectly -- only a single AS in the AS_SET are by far the most often used incorrectly; only a single AS in the AS_SET are by far the
common cases. Also, very often the same AS appears in the most common cases. Also, very often the same AS appears in the
AS_SEQUENCE and the AS_SET in the BGP update. The occurrence of AS_SEQUENCE and the AS_SET in the BGP update. The occurrence of
reserved AS numbers ([IANA-SP-ASN]) is also somewhat frequent. reserved AS numbers ([IANA-SP-ASN]) is also somewhat frequent.
Because the aggregation involving AS_SETs is very rarely used, the
reduction in table size provided by this is extremely small, and any
advantage thereof is outweighed by additional complexity in BGP. As
noted above, AS_SETs also pose impediments to implementation of new
BGP security technologies.

3. Recommendations 3. Recommendations
BGP speakers conforming to this document (i.e., conformant BGP BGP speakers conforming to this document (i.e., conformant BGP
speakers) MUST NOT locally generate BGP UPDATE messages containing speakers) SHOULD NOT locally generate BGP UPDATE messages containing
AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET. Conformant BGP speakers SHOULD NOT send BGP AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET. Conformant BGP speakers SHOULD NOT send BGP
UPDATE messages containing AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET. Upon receipt of UPDATE messages containing AS_SETs. Upon receipt of such messages,
such messages, conformant BGP speakers SHOULD use the "Treat-as- conformant BGP speakers SHOULD use the "Treat-as-withdraw" error
withdraw" error handling behavior as per [RFC7606]. handling behavior as per [RFC7606].
If a network operator wishes to consider BGP UPDATE messages with If a network operator wishes to consider BGP UPDATE messages with
AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET (received from an external peer) for path AS_SETs received from an external BGP peers, they MAY have a feature
selection, they MAY have a feature (knob) in their BGP speaker to opt (knob) in their implementation to do so on a per-peer basis. The
to do so on a per peer basis. The operator should understand the operator should understand the full implications of choosing this
full implications of choosing this option. There is no knob option.
concerning locally generated BGP UPDATE messages, i.e., as stated
before a conformant BGP speaker must not locally generate BGP UPDATE
messages with AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET.
Network operators MUST NOT locally generate any new announcements Network operators SHOULD NOT locally generate any new announcements
containing AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET. If they have announced routes containing AS_SETs.
with AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET in them, then they SHOULD withdraw those
routes and re-announce routes for the aggregate or component prefixes
(i.e., the more specific routes subsumed by the previously aggregated
route) without AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET in the updates.
It is worth noting that new BGP security technologies (such as those BGP security technologies (such as those that take advantage of X.509
that take advantage of X.509 extensions for IP addresses and AS extensions for IP addresses and AS identifiers ([RFC3779], [RFC6480]
identifiers [RFC3779] [RFC6480] [RFC6811] [RFC8205]) might not [RFC6811], [RFC8205]) might not support routes with AS_SETs or
support routes with AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET in them, and may treat AS_CONFED_SETs in them. [RFC6907], Sections 7.1.8 - 7.1.12
routes containing them as infeasible even before the updated BGP in recommends that routes containing AS_SETs be considered RPKI Invalid.
this document is implemented.
4. Updates to Existing RFCs 4. Updates to Existing RFCs
This document deprecates the AS_SET (type 1) AS_PATH segment type This document deprecates the origination of BGP routes with AS_SET
from [RFC4271]. BGP speakers conforming to this document (i.e., (type 1) AS_PATH segments. ([RFC4271], Section 4.3.) BGP speakers
conformant BGP speakers) MUST NOT locally generate BGP UPDATE conforming to this document -- i.e., conformant BGP speakers --
messages containing AS_SET. Conformant BGP speakers SHOULD NOT send SHOULD NOT originate BGP UPDATE messages containing AS_SETs. Upon
BGP UPDATE messages containing AS_SET. Upon receipt of such receipt of BGP routes containing AS_SETs, conformant BGP speakers
messages, conformant BGP speakers SHOULD use the "Treat-as-withdraw" SHOULD use the "Treat-as-withdraw" error handling behavior as per
error handling behavior as per [RFC7606]. [RFC7606].
This document deprecates the AS_CONFED_SET (type 4) AS_PATH segment 4.1. BGP AS_PATH "Brief" Aggregation
type from [RFC5065]. Conformant BGP speakers MUST NOT locally
generate BGP UPDATE messages containing AS_CONFED_SET. Conformant
BGP speakers SHOULD NOT send BGP UPDATE messages containing
AS_CONFED_SET. Upon receipt of such messages, conformant BGP
speakers SHOULD use the "Treat-as-withdraw" error handling behavior
as per [RFC7606].
Wherever mentions of AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET occur in [RFC4271] and [RFC4271], Sections 9.1.4 and 9.2.2.2, describes BGP aggregation
[RFC5065], appropriate modification or elimination of the text must procedures. [RFC4271], Appendix F.6 describes a generally
be made in future RFCs that would replace these RFCs, consistent with unimplemented "Complex AS_PATH Aggregation" procedure.
the deprecation of AS_SET and AS_CONFED_SET.
[RFC4271], Section 5.1.6 describing the ATOMIC_AGGREGATE Path
Attribute notes that:
| When a BGP speaker aggregates several routes for the purpose of
| advertisement to a particular peer, the AS_PATH of the aggregated
| route normally includes an AS_SET formed from the set of ASes from
| which the aggregate was formed. In many cases, the network
| administrator can determine if the aggregate can safely be
| advertised without the AS_SET, and without forming route loops.
|
| If an aggregate excludes at least some of the AS numbers present
| in the AS_PATH of the routes that are aggregated as a result of
| dropping the AS_SET, the aggregated route, when advertised to the
| peer, SHOULD include the ATOMIC_AGGREGATE attribute.
When BGP AS_PATH aggregation is done according to the Section 9.2.2.2
procedures and any resulting AS_SETs are discarded, this is typically
referred to as "brief" aggreation in implementations. This results
in an AS_PATH that has the property (from Section 9.2.2.2):
| determine the longest leading sequence of tuples (as defined
| above) common to all the AS_PATH attributes of the routes to be
| aggregated. Make this sequence the leading sequence of the
| aggregated AS_PATH attribute.
The ATOMIC_AGGREGATE Path Attribute is subsequently attached to the
BGP route, if AS_SETs are dropped.
4.2. Issues with "Brief" AS_PATH Aggregation and RPKI
While brief AS_PATH aggregation has the desirable property of not
containing AS_SETs, the resulting aggregated AS_PATH may contain an
unpredictable origin AS. Such an unpredictable origin ASes may
result in RPKI validation issues:
* Depending on the contributing routes to the aggregate route, the
resulting origin AS may vary.
* The presence of expected contributing routes may be unpredictable
due to route availability from BGP neighbors.
* In the presence of such varying origin ASes, it would be necessary
for the resource holder to register Route Origin Authorizations
(ROAs) [RFC6482] for each potential origin AS that may result from
the expected aggregated AS_PATHs.
4.3. Recommendations to Mitigate Unpredictable AS_PATH origins for RPKI
Purposes
In order to ensure a consistent BGP origin AS is announced for
aggregate BGP routes for implementations of "brief" BGP aggregation,
the implementation should be configured to truncate the AS_PATH after
the right-most instance of the desired origin AS for the aggregate.
If the resulting AS_PATH would be truncated from the otherwise
expected result of BGP AS_PATH aggregation (an AS_SET would be
generated, or ASes are removed from the "longest leading sequence" of
ASes), the ATOMIC_AGGREGATE Path Attribute SHALL be attached. This
is consistent with the intent of Section 5.1.6 of [RFC4271].

aggregation. In brief aggregation, the AGGREGATOR attribute is aggregation. In brief aggregation, the AGGREGATOR attribute is
included but the AS_SET or AS_CONFED_SET attribute is not included. included but the AS_SET attribute is not included.

aggregated to p/22, then p/22 will not be announced to AS1, AS2, AS3, aggregated to p/22, then p/22 will not be announced to AS1, AS2, AS3,

6. Security Considerations 6. Security Considerations
This document obsoletes the use of aggregation techniques that create This document obsoletes the use of aggregation techniques that create
AS_SETs or AS_CONFED_SETs. Obsoleting these path segment types from AS_SETs. Obsoleting these path segment types from BGP and removal of
BGP and removal of the related code from implementations would the related code from implementations would potentially decrease the
potentially decrease the attack surface for BGP. Deployments of new attack surface for BGP. Deployments of new BGP security technologies
BGP security technologies [RFC6480] [RFC6811] [RFC8205] benefit ([RFC6480], [RFC6811], [RFC8205]) benefit greatly if AS_SETs are not
greatly if AS_SET and AS_CONFED_SET are not used in BGP. used in BGP.
